III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Rule 400.4109 Program statement.
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth O brought knives into the facility.
Investigation I notified Complainant, also Youth N’s School Principal, that I was
assigned this complaint. She did not express any additional
concerns regarding Methodist Children’s Home.
I reviewed the facility’s history of licensing violations.
I notified Youth N’s Foster Care Worker that I was the DCWL
Consultant assigned to investigate the allegations. He expressed
no additional concerns.
On 9/13/23 I notified Chief Administrator (CA) of the allegations
via phone and requested names, incident reports, policies, and
staff schedules.
I arrived at the facility unannounced on 9/14/23 and reviewed
incident reports pertaining to knives and toy cap guns being
confiscated.
On 8/28/23 Residential Director wrote the following:
“Residents informed this writer that Youth A was possibly in
possession of a knife. This writer and Supervisor discovered the
knife on Youth A and confiscated it.”
I reviewed three additional reports by Supervisor dated 9/8/23. To
summarize, Youths A, O and N returned from AWOL together and
Supervisor confiscated three knives hidden outdoors and two toy
cap guns from Youth O’s and A’s pockets.
I interviewed Residential Director who has worked at the facility
over one year. He said on 8/28/23, Youth C informed him that
Youth A was in possession of a knife. Residential Director and
Supervisor asked Youth A to empty his pockets and Youth A
pulled out a folding knife. Residential Director provided a photo of
2

the knife confiscated from Youth A. It was a folding knife
approximately 6-inches long extended with a pointed tip and
jagged edge. Residential Director said Youth A was admitted to
the facility on 8/9/23 and had not been off campus except for a
staff supervised off-grounds activity to Dollar Tree on 8/27/23.
I asked Residential Director how and when youths are searched
for contraband. He said after returning from school in the
community, if they have a bag, it is searched. Upon returning
from AWOL or a home visit, staff wand youth with a metal
detector. Staff do not search youths when they return from an off-
grounds staff supervised activity.
I reviewed the facility’s search policy. It indicates youths can be
searched upon 1) return from school, 2) return from afterschool
activities, 3) return from AWOL, 4) return from a visit off grounds
(supervised or unsupervised), 5) return from on grounds
unsupervised visits and 6) probable cause which includes
information or suspicion.
I reviewed the facility’s policy for supervising youth while off-
grounds. It indicates staff are expected to be aware of the youth’s
whereabouts and within arms-length and earshot of staff. Staff
may not leave a youth unattended in the community for any length
of time.
I interviewed Supervisor who has worked at Methodist for three
months and has two years of experience at another child caring
institution. Supervisor said Youth A gave up the knife when asked
to on 8/28/23. He also recalled searching all of Youth A’s
belongings upon admission and said there was no knife.
On 9/8/23, Supervisor said he searched Youth’s O, A and N upon
their return from AWOL. “Youth A produced a cap gun and did not
say where he got it. Youth O reached in his pants and gave up a
second cap gun. Youth N confessed there were knives hidden
behind the cottage and took me to them. Youth N told me the
knives and cap guns came from Dollar Tree. Youth N said Youths
A and O ‘made’ him steal the knives while AWOL.”
Residential Director provided photos of the three knives and toy
cap guns that were confiscated on 9/8/23. The knives were the
same type as the single knife confiscated from Youth A on
8/28/23.
3

I interviewed Youth N, age 13. He admitted that he, Youth O and
Youth A “stole a bunch of stuff (two cap guns, two hair dyes and
three knives) the last time we went to Dollar Tree on Six Mile Rd.”
Youth N said Youths A and O removed the plastic covering from
the knives inside the Dollar Tree bathroom and referred to his
peers as “professionals at AWOLing and stealing.” Upon
returning from AWOL, Youth N said Youth A hid the knives
outdoors behind a cottage.
I interviewed Youth O, age 11. He said the knives and cap guns
were stolen on 9/8/23 and blamed Youth A for stealing them.
Youth O was unwilling to provide additional information.
I interviewed Youth A, age 11. He denied stealing anything from
the store on 9/8/23 and instead blamed Youths O and N. Youth A
told a story about Youths O and N dressed in all black and
wearing Halloween masks when they entered Dollar Tree while
Youth A remained outside. When I asked Youth A about the knife
that was found on his person on 8/28/23, he became angry and
stormed out of the interview room. As I walked to my car, I saw
Residential Director verbally de-escalating Youth A outdoors.
Youth A glared at me and uttered obscenities at me as I drove
away.
Analysis Youth A has only left the property twice since he was admitted on
8/9/23, once on 8/27/23 and a second time when AWOL on
9/8/23. The first time off-grounds was on 8/27/23, for a staff
supervised off-grounds activity to Dollar Tree. On 8/28/23 a knife
was confiscated from Youth A’s person based on information
provided to staff by another resident on that date. It can be
reasonably concluded that Youth A stole this knife during his first
trip to the Dollar Tree. However, there is no indication staff did not
follow the agency’s policies and procedures.
On 9/8/23, Youths A, O and N returned from AWOL, and three
knives and two toy cap guns were found outdoors on the property.
One or more of the youths admitted stealing the contraband from
Dollar Tree and hiding it outdoors until it was confiscated by staff.
A review of the facility’s search procedures indicates staff followed
the policy for searching youths.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
4

Rule Code & Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Section The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for
the continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth O forced Youth N to perform oral sex.
While AWOL together, Youth O exposed his private parts to
Youths N and A.
Investigation Residential Director said he moved Youth O to another cottage on
9/11/23 after learning sexual contact may have occurred between
Youths O and N while they were AWOL together on 9/8/23. He
estimated the boys were out of staff sight for 50 minutes before
they returned to campus. Residential Director said Youth N did
not tell anyone at the facility, but instead told his School Principal
that Youth O exposed himself or forced him to perform oral sex in
the woods.
When the boys went AWOL, Residential Director and Supervisor
said Staff 1 and 2 followed the agency’s supervision and AWOL
policies.
Youth N admitted that on 9/8/23 he, Youths A and O went AWOL
together. In the woods, “Youth O pulled down his pants and
Youth A pushed me to his front area. I ran back to the cottage.
Youths O and A came at me with metal poles.” Before reaching
the cottage, Youth N said Youth O threatened he “better not say
anything (to staff).” Youth N cried afterward because he said he
was traumatized. “I told the principal at school because I can trust
her. She’s kinder. I didn’t think the staff would care.”
Youth N denied that any sexual touching or penetration occurred
in the woods.
Youth O denied removing his pants or exposing himself to his
peers in the woods. All he said was “Youth A pushed me into
Youth N.”
Youth A denied that Youth O exposed himself in the woods.
5

On 9/22/23, I interviewed Staff 1 who has worked at the facility for
eight years. On 9/8/23 he said the boys were huddled up
outdoors and then ran into the woods together. Staff 1 said he
walked behind them but stopped once they got deep into the
woods. “I called Supervisor. Staff 2 got in the van (to canvas the
area) and I stayed back with the other kids.”
I interviewed Staff 2 on 9/22/23. As he sat down, he remarked
that he felt as if he was about to be “interrogated by the police.” I
explained my role as a licensing consultant reassuring him that I
was not a police officer.
Staff 2 said he has worked for the facility for five years. I asked
him to recall what the three youths were doing before they went
AWOL on 9/8/23. He said he did not know. I gave him the
incident reports he wrote pertaining to the AWOL to refresh his
memory. He scanned them and referred me back to the reports
which lacked precipitating factors and other details. After more
encouragement, Staff 2 said the youths ran toward the south part
of the property and he followed them on foot. When they reached
the woods, he said he got in a vehicle, drove up and down Six
Mile Road searching for them for 15 – 20 minutes, then drove to
the police station and filed missing persons reports.
I reviewed the facility’s AWOL policy. It indicates staff are
expected to make all efforts to maintain eyesight of the youth(s).
If youths leave the grounds, staff should get a van and follow
them. If youths AWOL but stay on campus and go into the woods,
staff should contact the supervisor, follow calmly on foot, and
verbally attempt to return them. Staff must follow youths as far as
possible without endangering their own safety. If youths retreat
further into the woods and staff lose eyesight of them, the police
should be contacted, and a missing persons reports filed.
Analysis Staff were appropriately supervising Youths A, O and N before
they went AWOL and followed the facility’s AWOL policy after they
went AWOL.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
